channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Samuel Jackson Traces the History of the Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade
item.description: A docuseries on slavery through the lens of sunken slave ships that never reached their destination — ships that became mass graves of kidnapped Africans.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: AP Slave Ships Productions Ltd./Cornelia Street’s Ships Ltd./EPIX
item.media:description: Samuel L. Jackson at the Point of No Return in Loango National Park in Gabon, in Central Africa.

item.title: Fires Scorch Oregon's Forests, Where the Economy Is Rooted in Its Trees
item.description: Oregon’s fate has always been intertwined with the forests that blanket the state. Now millions of trees are charred, and those who live from them face a future full of uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Kristina Barker for The New York Times

item.title: In the Most Litigated Election Ever, Early Democratic Wins but Few Clear Signals
item.description: Democrats won some important legal battles in the critical states of Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania. But the legal wars over the 2020 election are just getting going.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wines and Nick Corasaniti
item.category: Green Party of the United States
item.media:credit: Mark Felix/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A primary election in Houston this year. A state appeals court on Friday denied a Republican attempt to stop the mailing of absentee ballot applications to Harris County voters, who are heavily Democratic.

item.title: A Coronavirus Infection Complicates Portland-Area Firefighting Efforts
item.description: A fire incident management team went into temporary isolation this week in Washington State after a member of a resupply crew tested positive for the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:credit: Will Matsuda for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pod of tents at Amboy Territorial Park in Amboy, Wash., for firefighters battling the Big Hollow Fire. Visitors must be approved and get their temperatures checked.

item.title: Voting Alone
item.description: The national bard of community long warned about what isolation would do to us. Now our democracy is in the midst of an experiment no one asked for.
item.dc:creator: Marc Tracy
item.media:credit: Tristan Spinski for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert D. Putnam has been isolating at his home in southern New Hampshire. He believes the internet can supplement, not replace, real life connections.

item.title: How One District Got Its Students Back Into Classrooms
item.description: Cajon Valley in California is doing something that many lower-income districts have postponed: offering in-person instruction.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Anderson
item.media:credit: Sandy Huffaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: After a set of marathon negotiations in late August, the Cajon Valley Union School District announced a hybrid plan with a mix of in-person and at-home instruction.

item.title: Outside the Supreme Court, Mourners Honor Ginsburg’s Legacy
item.description: People of all ages flocked on Saturday to the building in Washington, leaving flowers, posters and messages scrawled in chalk.
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial for Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg outside the Supreme Court on Saturday.

item.title: Trump Supporters Disrupt Early Voting in Virginia
item.description: A group waving Trump flags and chanting “four more years” created a commotion at a polling location in Fairfax, Va. A county official said some voters and staff members felt intimidated.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Trump gathered outside the Fairfax County Government Center with flags and banners, chanting near residents who were waiting in line for early voting.

item.title: Joe Biden’s Court Vacancy Plan: More Talk of Health Care and the Pandemic
item.description: Mr. Biden has spent months assailing President Trump’s handling of the coronavirus. With a bitter Supreme Court confirmation battle looming, he will seek to link the vacancy to the pandemic and the future of health care.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher, Katie Glueck and Thomas Kaplan
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. at campaign event in Tampa, Fla., this past week.

item.title: ‘This Is Why We Wanted This Guy’: Conservatives Push Trump to Fill Court Seat Quickly
item.description: Social conservatives and evangelical groups sprang into action after the death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, encouraging a speedy confirmation and rallying support for embattled Senate Republicans.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters
item.media:credit: Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Faith and Freedom Coalition, founded by Ralph Reed, is holding events for embattled Senate Republicans.

item.title: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez reflects on Ginsburg’s legacy and says Biden should hold off on a list of judges.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca R. Ruiz
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez on Saturday lauded Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg and said the fact that her death had touched off a political furor was a sign of an unhealthy democracy.

item.title: Ginsburg Expected to Lie in Repose at the Supreme Court
item.description: Plans for a commemoration and services have yet to be made final, but large crowds are expected to pay their respects for a justice who became a feminist icon and liberal hero.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial for Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg outside the Supreme Court on Saturday.

item.title: Susan Collins says she opposes holding a vote on a replacement for Ginsburg before the election.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, is considered a swing vote and is facing a tough challenge from Sara Gideon, her Democratic opponent.

item.title: Mark Kelly vs Martha McSally: Why Democrats See Hope on Supreme Court Fight
item.description: If Mark Kelly wins a special election, he could end up casting a crucial vote on President Trump’s nominee.
item.dc:creator: Hank Stephenson and Glenn Thrush
item.media:credit: Conor E. Ralph for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Kelly, the Democratic Senate candidate in Arizona, has been ahead of Senator Martha McSally, a Republican, in recent polls.

item.title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg: Photos of Her Rise to the Supreme Court
item.description: Pictures capture moments in her legal career, from law school professor to associate justice on the high court.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Shadow of Merrick Garland Hangs Over the Next Supreme Court Fight
item.description: The fight over the confirmation of Judge Garland in 2016 set the tone for an even more brutal battle over who should succeed Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Barack Obama nominated Judge Merrick B. Garland to fill Justice Antonin Scalia’s seat in 2016.

item.title: Ginsburg’s Death Further Polarizes Voters Just Weeks Before Election
item.description: Republicans want to push forward. Democrats are seething. A bitterly divided nation gets more so as a Supreme Court nomination fight looms.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry/Getty Images
item.media:description: People protested outside the home of Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, in Louisville, Ky., on Saturday. Mr. McConnell has said he will work to advance a vote on Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s replacement.

item.title: What Key Senators Are Saying About Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg's Replacement
item.description: The political jockeying intensified on Saturday about what the Senate would do to fill the vacancy on the U.S. Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, said he would move forward with President Trump’s nominee to replace Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg on the Supreme Court.

item.title: Here Are The Senators to Watch in Supreme Court Justice Vote
item.description: Republicans hold a narrow majority in the Senate, meaning they can only afford to lose a few votes in their push to confirm a replacement for Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg. Here are the potential swing votes.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Lisa Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, is often seen as a swing vote and has said she would not support filling a Supreme Court vacancy so close to an election.

item.title: Ricin Is Said to Have Been Sent to White House
item.description: Letters with the lethal substance were also sent to local law enforcement offices in Texas, an official said. Investigators are trying to find out who sent them and whether more were circulating through the postal system.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner
item.media:credit: Jacquelyn Martin/Associated Press
item.media:description: An envelope addressed to the White House contained a substance that federal investigators have confirmed as ricin, according to a law enforcement official.

item.title: Ginsburg’s death revives calls for court packing.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: The flag was flown at half staff outside of the Supreme Court the morning after Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg died.

item.title: Wait or nominate? Many voters support doing what is best for their party, but for some, the court fight looms large.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens, Jonathan Martin and Jon Hurdle
item.media:credit: Elaine Thompson/Associated Press
item.media:description: Some undecided voters are weighing whether the Supreme Court vacancy will affect their decision.

item.title: A Republican senator argues a vote should not take place until after the election.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin

item.title: Democratic and Republican Fundraising Rises Over Supreme Court Confirmation Battle
item.description: Justice Ginsburg’s death on Friday night plunged Washington into what is certain to be a fierce clash as liberals seek to stop President Trump and the Republican-led Senate from confirming a replacement before Inauguration Day.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: People who came to pay respects to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg after her death on Friday confronting a conservative protester, left, outside the Supreme Court.

item.title: How Mitch McConnell Can Quickly Push Through Trump’s Supreme Court Nominee
item.description: The rules and partisan breakdown of the Senate make it possible for Republicans to swiftly confirm President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee. Here’s how.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell has never shied away from an opportunity to pack the judiciary with conservative nominees.

item.title: Capturing the Faces of Climate Migration
item.description: A Times Magazine series examines how climate change will force millions worldwide to move. Recently, Meridith Kohut photographed people on the front lines of this shift. In America.
item.dc:creator: Libby Peterson

item.title: U.S. Reimposes U.N. Sanctions on Iran Over Objections of World Powers
item.description: The full range of the sanctions were announced on Saturday evening in Washington, but it is unclear how effective they will be.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Abedin Taherkenareh/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A bazaar in Tehran on Wednesday. The Trump administration said it would reimpose United Nations sanctions against Iran.

item.title: Overlooked No More: Mabel Ping-Hua Lee, Suffragist With a Distinction
item.description: Lee stood out as a Chinese immigrant, giving speeches, writing articles and helping to lead a 10,000-strong march through the streets of New York City when she was just a teenager.
item.dc:creator: Jia Lynn Yang
item.media:credit: Records of the Immigration and Naturalization Service/National Archives
item.media:description: Mabel Ping-Hua Lee, who helped coordinate one of the biggest suffrage parades in U.S. history.

item.title: 'Without Delay,' Trump Presses for New Supreme Court Justice
item.description: The president is likely to nominate a successor this coming week to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who died on Friday, but Senate Republicans are weighing whether they have the votes to confirm his choice before the Nov. 3 election.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump was poised to quickly nominate a successor to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg after her death on Friday.

item.title: Who is on President Trump's List of Supreme Court Nominees?
item.description: President Trump has vowed to fill the vacancy created by the death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg “without delay.” Here is who might fill the seat.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse and Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Robert Franklin/South Bend Tribune, via AP

item.title: Mourners Gather at Vigils Across the Country in Ginsburg’s Honor
item.description: The death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the second woman appointed to the Supreme Court, has injected new uncertainty into the presidential election and set off a torrent of political maneuvering.
item.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
item.media:description: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg in her chambers in 2013.

item.title: AstraZeneca Releases Blueprints for Virus Vaccine Trial Amid Safety Scrutiny
item.description: A surge of infections in the Southwest and the Midwest is partly driving an uptick in cases nationally. The eight remaining members of the Supreme Court are expected to hear arguments next month via telephone.
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: What is Court Packing? Supreme Court Vacancy Revives Idea From FDR
item.description: The idea recalls a move by President Franklin D. Roosevelt, who hoped to push older justices to retire.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners on the steps of the U.S. Supreme Court after the death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg on Friday.

item.title: Victim in 1963 Alabama Church Bombing Seeks State Restitution
item.description: Sarah Collins Rudolph lost her right eye at age 12 when a bomb went off at the 16th Street Baptist Church and killed four Black girls, including her sister.
item.dc:creator: Allyson Waller
item.media:credit: Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times
item.media:description: Sarah Collins Rudolph in 2002. She lost an eye in the bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church in 1963. The explosion “shook the whole city of Birmingham,” she said.

item.title: Lost World War II Submarine Is Found in Southeast Asia
item.description: The U.S.S. Grenadier was scuttled in April 1943 after being attacked by Japanese bombers. Surviving crew members were tortured at a prison camp for more than two years, according to accounts.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jean Luc Rivoire
item.media:description: Four divers believe they have located the U.S.S. Grenadier, which was scuttled off the coast of Thailand in April 1943 after being attacked by Japanese planes.

item.title: How The Ginsburg Vacancy Injects New Uncertainty Into Trump vs Biden
item.description: After the death of Ruth Bader Ginsburg, it was not clear that President Trump’s right-wing coalition would be more motivated by a confirmation fight than the alliance of liberals and moderates supportive of Mr. Biden would be.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Burns and Adam Nagourney
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg at the Supreme Court in 2018.

item.title: On Venus, Cloudy With a Chance of Microbial Life
item.description: Astrobiologists shift their gaze, and speculations, to Earth’s broiling sister planet.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: JPL/NASA
item.media:description: An image of Venus made with data recorded by NASA’s Mariner 10 spacecraft in 1974.

item.title: Mount Wilson Observatory, Icon of Cosmology, 'Declared Safe' From Fires
item.description: The birthplace of modern cosmology “has been declared safe” from the wildfires that have ravaged the surrounding area in Southern California.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firefighters atop Mount Wilson in Los Angeles on Wednesday.

item.title: As U.S. Increases Pressure, Iran Adheres to Toned-Down Approach
item.description: The Trump administration has ramped up its criticism of Iran, but Tehran has chosen a path of restraint, intelligence showed.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, David E. Sanger, Ronen Bergman and Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, during a video call with President Hassan Rouhani in Tehran. The Trump administration plans to reimpose sanctions on Iran.

item.title: How to Pack an Emergency Bag
item.description: The first step toward a solid evacuation plan is pulling together all the gear you need, before you need it.
item.dc:creator: A.C. Shilton
item.media:credit: Christian Monterrosa for The New York Times

item.title: This Week in the 2020 Presidential Race: Ruth Bader Ginsburg's Death
item.description: The news arrived late Friday night while Joe Biden and President Trump were both campaigning in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon and Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. participated in a CNN town hall near Scranton, Pa., on Thursday.

item.title: Shooting in Rochester Leaves 2 Dead and Over a Dozen Injured
item.description: The violence was the latest trouble for a city where law enforcement has come under scrutiny over the suffocation death of Daniel Prude, a Black man, in police custody.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: 13 WHAM, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The authorities had not yet made any arrests in the shooting in Rochester, N.Y., and said the 14 victims who were wounded were 17 to 23 years old.
